docs.lead_paragraph: The number of teenagers and children being prescribed antidepressants in the United States dropped 18 percent over the last year after studies found that the medicines appeared to lead some to become suicidal, according to one provider of drug benefits. In a study done at the behest of The New York Times, Medco Health Solutions found that 43,859 of the roughly 3.5 million children and teenagers for whom the company provided drug benefits in July, or 1.26 percent, were prescribed antidepressants that month. That is down from 60,902 children and teenagers, or 1.69 percent of the total, who were prescribed the drugs a year earlier. It was the first decline in prescriptions for antidepressants among teenagers and children in years, the company found.

headline.main: Study Finds Less Youth Antidepressant Use

docs.abstract: Medco Health Solutions study finds number of teenagers and children being prescribed antidepressants in US dropped 18 percent over last year after studies found that medicines appear to lead some to become suicidal; Medco finding is at odds with information provided last week by Food and Drug Administration to its advisory committee; FDA claims prescriptions of antidepressants for children and teenagers continued to rise by 7 percent this year despite growing controversy about safety of drugs; graph
docs.snippet: While the FDA contends otherwise, new data show that sales of the antidepressants known as SSRIs have declined.

docs.lead_paragraph: MAKE trouble your ally. That's the advice experts have for would-be entrepreneurs. Turmoil -- economic or social -- creates opportunity, even as it pushes managers and other employees out of their corporate niches. From such upheaval come new demands for services -- from overloaded working people, from bricks-and-mortar companies grappling with the information age.

headline.main: Looking for a Chance by Looking for Trouble

docs.snippet: Turmoil  economic or social  creates opportunity, say experts to would-be entrepreneurs, and from such upheaval comes new demands for services.

docs.lead_paragraph: Grace Drake still hopes that someday she will meet Mr. Right and have a family the old-fashioned way. But as the program director of a fertility clinic in Austin, Tex., Ms. Drake, 35, sees women every day who are in their 30's and 40's and want desperately to have children but cannot. So she decided to take out some insurance: She froze her eggs.

headline.main: For Women Worried About Fertility, Egg Bank Is a New Option

docs.abstract: Extend Fertility, company that offers egg freezing to women wanting to preserve ability to have children later in life, now has clinics in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Dallas and New York; only around 100 babies worldwide have been born using frozen eggs; Christy Jones, Harvard University MBA and founder of company, acknowledges that process is expensive, but holds that all fertility-related procedures have high price tag; process of freezing eggs, which requires dehydration to prevent damaging ice crystals from forming, described; American Society for Reproductive Medicine warns that freezing eggs should not be used as way for older women to have babies, but recognizes that technology is advancing at rapid pace; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For single women who want children, egg freezing may be a reproductive insurance policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Closer Look at Kerry's Record on Taxes At almost every campaign stop, President Bush accuses Senator John Kerry of having voted repeatedly for higher taxes on the middle class and of proposing more than $2 trillion in spending the country cannot afford. There is a kernel of truth in both statements. But like many charges the candidates exchange, they are exaggerated to the point of distortion. WHAT BUSH SAYS Here is how Mr. Bush framed his charge at a rally in Pennsylvania last week:
docs.abstract: Fact Check: Pres Bush repeatedly accuses Sen John Kerry of having voted many times for higher taxes on middle class and of proposing more than $2 trillion in spending country cannot afford; Bush statements are exaggerations of truth to point of distortion; close look at what Bush says and at the facts (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush's accusation that Senator John Kerry has voted for higher taxes on the middle class contains a kernel of truth, but is exaggerated.

docs.lead_paragraph: NOT long after Lisa Gussack hung out her shingle as a midwife in 1980, she realized the job would involve far more than delivering babies. Pregnant women complained of backaches, new mothers suffered from the blues, and fathers often got lost in all the excitement. ''Not to mention the needs of the babies themselves,'' Ms. Gussack said. Convinced that mothers-to-be would benefit from massage therapy and that those with newborns might perk up in a support group, Ms. Gussack turned her attention to holistic health.
docs.abstract: Article on Lisa Gussack, who has been practicing midwifery in her home and referring clients to others for wide variety of support services since 1980; Gussack has opened Full Circle Family Care, one-stop health center in White Plains, NY; Gussack, limited by state laws, set up business as management association, leases building and rents space to doctors and other health professionals; photos (M)
docs.snippet: NOT long after Lisa Gussack hung out her shingle as a midwife in 1980, she realized the job would involve far more than delivering babies. Pregnant women complained of backaches, new mothers suffered from the blues, and fathers often got lost in all...

docs.lead_paragraph: Women's Health Connecticut, an association of 150 of the state's obstetricians and gynecologists, announced last week that its members had decided not to assess a planned $500 surcharge to patients for delivering babies. Nancy Bernstein, the president and chief officer of Women's Health Connecticut, said the doctors had originally planned to begin the surcharge on Sept. 1 to offset the high cost of malpractice insurance, if the State Legislature did not pass tort reform.

headline.main: OB-Gyns Drop Efforts For a Delivery Surcharge

docs.abstract: Women's Health Connecticut, association of 150 obstetricians and gynecologists, decides against assessing planned $500 surcharge on patients for delivering babies to offset high cost of malpractice insurance (S)
docs.snippet: Women's Health Connecticut, an association of 150 of the state's obstetricians and gynecologists, announced last week that its members had decided not to assess a planned $500 surcharge to patients for delivering babies.    Nancy Bernstein, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: WORKPLACE stress is back in the news. American workers are frazzled to the point of illness, experts say, and enlightened employers are offering yoga classes, massage and other palliatives to combat the problem. Talk about civilization and its discontents. If you find the modern, air-conditioned workplace stressful -- all that e-mail! -- just think back to the work most Americans used to do. Men were farmhands, coal miners, steelworkers and the like, working every day with the risk of death or destitution hovering nearby. Women who worked outside the home were poorly paid for difficult jobs -- often as domestics or millworkers, toiling at the whim of wealthy employers. Opportunities for minorities were extremely limited, and discrimination against blacks, for example, was so acute that most were excluded from all but the most menial jobs. Now that's stress.
docs.snippet: Though workplace stress is back in the news, the problems that U.S. workers face today don't compare with those faced by earlier generations.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a campaign that has been devoted to Vietnam, Iraq and the economy, there is one issue that John Kerry would do well to bring up, an issue that has received little attention this political season: trade. I would love to see Senator Kerry announce that if elected he will immediately convene a summit meeting on international trade and globalism to be held in Columbus, Ohio. He should announce that the meeting will be an annual event and that he intends to invite American business, political, and education leaders to join him. The meeting's agenda would not be so different from what the campaign's agenda should be -- to help us reduce our current trade account deficit, to forge a plan to increase the size and vitality of our middle class, to design a way to ensure health and retirement benefits in an age of growing uncertainty, to see to it that we sustain the public and private investment needed for growth, to construct an agriculture policy that promotes healthy rural communities in America and around the world, and to balance our desire for growth with our need to conserve natural resources.

headline.main: What Should Kerry Do?; Trading Up

docs.abstract: New School University president Bob Kerrey Op-Ed article contends that Sen John Kerry should announce that if he is elected president, he will convene summit meeting on international trade and globalism; holds that no issue is going to strain political process in US more than trade (M)
docs.snippet: There is one issue that John Kerry would do well to bring up, an issue that has received little attention this political season: trade.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Anna Carol Freitag and Michael John Luke Kedersha were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Thorne, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Neil O'Connell, also a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony. Dr. Freitag-Kedersha, 39, is an endocrinologist in private practice in Stamford, Conn. She is also a director of the AmeriCares Diabetes Clinic, a free health clinic in South Norwalk, Conn. The bride graduated from Smith and received her medical degree from the University of Connecticut. She is a daughter of Sofia Freitag of Norwalk and the late Arthur Freitag.

Senator John Kerry faces substantial obstacles in his bid to unseat President Bush, with voters saying he has not laid out a case for why he wants to be president and expressing strong concern about his ability to manage an international crisis, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Less than seven weeks before Election Day, Americans continue to think that the nation is heading in the wrong direction and are distressed about how Mr. Bush has handled the economy. Yet the president, apparently lifted as much by what Mr. Kerry has done wrong as by what Mr. Bush has done right in the campaign, has an eight-point lead among registered voters, the poll found.

headline.main: BUSH OPENS LEAD DESPITE UNEASE VOICED IN SURVEY

docs.abstract: Results of New York Times/CBS News poll show Pres Bush taking 8-point lead over Sen John Kerry among registered voters; many respondents feel country is headed in wrong direction and are distressed about how Bush has handled economy, yet majority feel Kerry has not laid out his case and worry about his ability to manage international crisis; neither candidate is strongly trusted on his military record; Kerry fares little better than Bush on economy; recent polls with different findings suggest electorate is in flux; findings suggest that Kerry has been hurt by attack ads from Swift Boat Veterans for Truth; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry faces substantial obstacles in his bid to unseat President Bush, with voters saying he has not laid out a case for why he wants to be president.
